node.title: Bug Report: CLI Fails with Mismatched Function Call/Response Error
node.body:
### What happened?


  Bug Report: CLI Fails with Mismatched Function Call/Response Error

  Title:
  CLI Bug: INVALID_ARGUMENT due to mismatched function call and response parts.


  Description:
  The Gemini CLI client is frequently and consistently failing with a 400 INVALID_ARGUMENT error. The error message indicates a
  core logic issue where the number of function responses being sent by the client does not match the number of function calls
  requested by the model.


  This is not tied to a specific user command or tool, but appears to be a fundamental bug in how the CLI handles the tool-use
  communication loop with the Gemini API. The issue renders the CLI client unreliable and largely unusable.

  Error Message:


   1 {
   2   "error": {
   3     "code": 400,
   4     "message": "Please ensure that the number of function response parts is equal to the number of function call parts 
     of the function call turn.",
   5     "status": "INVALID_ARGUMENT"
   6   }
   7 }


  To Reproduce:
  The error occurs during general interaction with the CLI. Any user prompt that leads the model to attempt a tool call can
  trigger this bug. The failure is in the client-side logic, not in the user's specific input.


  Expected Behavior:
  The CLI client should correctly format and send one response part for every function call part requested by the model, allowing
  the conversation to proceed without error.


  Environment:
   * Tool: Gemini CLI
   * Model: (Not model-specific, but observed with Gemini Pro)
   * Impact: Critical. The CLI is not reliably functional.

While doing so, I have been saving the chat with Gemini about this bug and then we both (sic) have been tinkering with A/B testing. And when I was about to triumphally declare to Gemini "I have found the MCPs, they are  somewhere in the other set!", then ... the `settings.json` containing by now the very same 4 barebone ones (that used to work just a minute before) resulted in the same error, out of the blue, when the session was restored.  

Notes: changing API keys via `/auth` does not help; `/clear` does not help. 


I have read the related https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/issues/3764, https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/issues/2141 (some from 3 weeks ago) and they suggest the chat history corruption instead of MPC settings being messed up, after all.

At any rate, I have spent 2 hours on it and am none the wiser, despite being a competent Gemini CLI user by now, so this cryptic error needs at least an "upgrade" so that then end users shall know which backend or middleware (MCPs still?) or maybe the front-end itself (Gemini CLI's code?) is to blame...

node.title: INVALID_ARGUMENT resuming a saved chat (400 BadRequest)

nodes.body: same problem for me - looks like a bug
Im stuck at this exact point

Same, it's very annoying. My workaround was to open a new chat in cursor with gemini 2.5 pro, then do this:

1. Ask it to look through this link to find where conversations are stored: https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/tree/main
2.  Ask it to find the conversation that crashed and copy the it into a non-hidden folder
3. Start a new conversation in gemini-cli and @ the file so it can read the last conversation.

I can take a stab at this.

**Initial Analysis**

 **The Problem**

  When loading a saved chat that contained function calls and responses:
  1. The code was displaying function call/response items in the UI, even though they have no
  displayable text
  2. This created a mismatch in the chat history where the Gemini API expected function calls
  and responses to be properly paired

  **The Solution**

  Modified /packages/cli/src/ui/hooks/slashCommandProcessor.ts to:
  1. Continue adding all items to the chat history (to maintain API compatibility)
  2. Only display items that contain text content and aren't function calls/responses
  3. Add a check hasOnlyText to identify items that contain only text parts
  4. Skip displaying items with function calls or responses while keeping them in the history

node.title: How to use claude model through vertexai
node.body:
Although Vertex AI can use the Claude models, when I set the environment variable `GEMINI_MODEL` to `claude-sonnet-4@20250514` and ran the gemini CLI, I got the following error:
```
âœ• [API Error: countTokens is infeasible for projects/{PROJECT_ID}/locations/us-east5/publishers/google/models/claude-sonnet-4@20250514 (Status: INVALID_ARGUMENT)]
```
It seems this happens because the modelâ€™s publisher is listed as `google` rather than `anthropic`.
Is there any way to change the publisher in the gemini-cli? 
Also, are Claude models intentionally blocked?

nodes.body: We're using [the GenAI library ](https://github.com/googleapis/js-genai) for access vertex so we have all it's limitations. I can say that excluding Claude wasn't intentional on our part (though I'll be honest, I didn't realize you could use it through Vertex).
@scidomino maybe LiteLLM could be an option to circumvent some of these limitations at least for a number of LLMs providers out there.

I haven't gotten around to VertexAI yet but I have direct anthropic support and openai here: 

https://github.com/acoliver/llxprt-code

any openai compatible "should work" 

This is a fork I'm keeping roughly up to date with head. In addition it supports the OpenAI responses model. I've tested with local, open router, Fireworks and groq. 

Just set the openai provider, a baseurl and keyfile or key. You should be able to use most anything. BTW you can also go directly to openai or anthropic.

We haven't actually gotten this to work, but at least from looking at the code, this should work:
```
gemini --model=publishers/anthropic/models/claude-3-5-haiku
```

(We just enabled the model, so it's possible we just need to wait a bit longer.)

node.title: API Error
node.body:

Here is a simplified explanation of the proposed change. The Problem (Current Behavior): Imagine you're editing the sentence "The quick brown fox jumps." to "The fast red cat leaps." The current code is like an editor who makes one-word changes at a time. It sees: 1. quick -> fast (Okay, that's a change, I'm done with this spot.) 2. brown -> red (Okay, another change, done.) 3. fox -> cat (And another.) It treats them as three separate, unrelated edits. In the code example you provided, it sees Goldman -> J.P., stops, and treats it as a finished change, then moves on to Sachs -> Morgan as a separate change. The Proposed Solution (The "Greedy" Approach): The new logic tells the editor to be a bit smarter and "greedier." Instead of stopping after the first word, it will look ahead to see if the next words are also part of the same substitution. It will now see: 1. quick -> fast... (Wait, let me peek ahead...) 2. The next word is brown -> red... (This looks like it's part of the same change, let me grab it too...) 3. The next word is fox -> cat... (Still part of it, I'll take it.) 4. The next word is jumps -> leaps. (Okay, this whole phrase seems to be one single change.) The result is that it correctly groups "The quick brown fox jumps" into "The fast red cat leaps" as a single, logical edit. How it Addresses Your Concern: You're right to be cautious about it being too greedy. Hereâ€™s how we prevent it from breaking other things: 1. It's Not Infinitely Greedy: The "greediness" is limited by a pre-existing configuration setting (MAX_SUBSTITUTION_SCAN_LENGTH). It will only look ahead a reasonable number of characters before it stops. It won't try to group changes from opposite ends of the document. 2. It Only Groups Direct Substitutions: This logic only applies when a removed word/phrase is immediately followed by an added word/phrase (or separated by simple whitespace). It won't incorrectly group an added section from one paragraph with a removed section from another. 3. It Doesn't Change Other Logic: This change is isolated to the findAndCombineSubstitution function. It doesn't affect how simple additions or deletions are handled elsewhere. In short, the change makes the function smarter about identifying multi-word substitutions, leading to a cleaner and more accurate output, without introducing risks to other parts of the system. The short answer is: no, the change I'm proposing will not break natural sentence boundaries because the logic for substitution grouping and the logic for semantic chunking are separate. Let me break it down: 1. Substitution Grouping (`findAndCombineSubstitution`): This function's only job is to look for a pattern of removed text immediately followed by added text (allowing for whitespace in between). It's what turns removed("Goldman") + added("J.P.") into a single logical change. * It does not analyze the content. It doesn't know what a period is. It only sees the type of change. * The "greedy" change I'm proposing simply allows it to continue looking for more removed/added pairs in the immediate vicinity, so it can group Goldman Sachs -> J.P. Morgan correctly. It will stop as soon as it hits a block of unchanged text that isn't just whitespace. 2. Semantic Chunking (`findSemanticChunkBoundary`): This is a completely separate function that runs at a different stage. Its job is to look at the stream of changes and decide where to split the content into large, efficient chunks for display. * This is the function that understands sentence boundaries. It explicitly looks for periods, commas, and newlines (., ,, \n) to find natural breaking points. * This function is what prevents a single display chunk from ending awkwardly in the middle of a sentence. In summary: Think of it as a two-step process: 1. First, we run the "greedy" substitution grouper to clean up the raw diff, correctly identifying multi-word changes. 2. Second, we feed that cleaned-up result into the semantic chunker, which then intelligently breaks the content into large display blocks based on sentence boundaries. The change to the first step makes its output better for the second step, but it doesn't change the rules the second step uses. The two systems work together but have distinct responsibilities. Therefore, the proposed change is safe. It will improve the grouping of substitutions without affecting how sentence boundaries are respected. node.title: Linear MCP Server breaks tool-calling
node.body: ## Describe the bug The error: [API Error: got status: 400 Bad Request. {"error":{"message":"{\n \"error\": {\n \"code\": 400,\n \"message\": \"* GenerateContentRequest.tools[0].function_declarations[45].parameters.properties[links].items.properties[url].format: only 'enum' and 'date-time' are supported for STRING type\\n* GenerateContentRequest.tools[0].function_declarations[46].parameters.properties[links].items.properties[url].format: only 'enum' and 'date-time' are supported for STRING type\\n\",\n \"status\": \"INVALID_ARGUMENT\"\n }\n}\n","code":400,"status":"Bad Request"}}] Linear MCP Settings: { "mcpServers": { "linear": { "command": "npx", "args": ["-y", "mcp-remote", "https://mcp.linear.app/sse"] } } } When I added the linear mcp to my settings.json, it breaks the gemini cli tool calling. It works if i remove the linear mcp (so in general the tool calling works with other mcp servers). ## Diagnostic Information * **CLI Version:** 0.1.0 * **Git Commit:** 852210e1 (local modifications) * **Operating System:** darwin v22.14.0 * **Sandbox Environment:** no sandbox * **Model Version:** gemini-2.5-pro * **Memory Usage:** 103.6 MB

node.title: API Errors - Code 400 when sending a prompt
node.body:
### What happened?

I rejected an edit file request from gemini cli and suddenly it started throwing errors from the next prompt infinitely until stopped. I have sent about 200+ prompts today (including rejecting a lot of responses) and no errors like this happened until now.
```
âœ• [API Error: [{
    "error": {
      "code": 400,
      "message": "Please ensure that the number of function response 
  parts is equal to the number of function call parts of the function
   call turn.",
      "errors": [
        {
          "message": "Please ensure that the number of function 
  response parts is equal to the number of function call parts of the
   function call turn.",
          "domain": "global",
          "reason": "badRequest"
        }
      ],
      "status": "INVALID_ARGUMENT"
    }
  }
  ]]
```

This keeps happening in that session, I suspect until I quit the session and start a new one.

### What did you expect to happen?

Expect it to continue with the discussion and code changes.

### Client information


*   **CLI Version:** 0.1.9
*   **Git Commit:** 34935d6
*   **Operating System:** darwin v24.1.0
*   **Sandbox Environment:** no sandbox

*   **Memory Usage:** 471.6 MB


### Login information

Google Account with Gemini Code Assist Standard plan.

_No response_

node.title: API Error: `Thinking_config.include_thoughts` when using `gemini -m gemini-2.5-flash-lite-preview-06-17`
node.body:
### What happened?

When attempting to use `gemini-2.5-flash-lite-preview-06-17` model, an API error occurs related to `Thinking_config.include_thoughts`.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Run the following command in the terminal:
   ```bash
   gemini -m gemini-2.5-flash-lite-preview-06-17
   ```
2. Provide any input (e.g., `test`).

The command fails with an API error message.

```
âœ• [API Error: {"error":{"message":"{
  "error": {
    "code": 400,
    "message": "Unable to submit request because
    Thinking_config.include_thoughts is only enabled when thinking is enabled..
    Learn more: https://cloud.google.com/vertex-ai/generative-ai/docs/model-reference/gemini",
    "status": "INVALID_ARGUMENT"
  }
}
","code":400,"status":"Bad Request"}}]
```


### What did you expect to happen?

The `gemini` command should process the input using the specified model without any API errors, and return a response.

### Client information

<details>

```sh
â”‚ About Gemini CLI                                                        â”‚
â”‚                                                                         â”‚
â”‚ CLI Version              0.1.4                                          â”‚

â”‚ Sandbox                  no sandbox                                     â”‚

</details>

Vertex AI

_No response_

node.title: GhidraMCP service fails with "Invalid function name" error when used standalone, but works in VS Code
node.body:
### What happened?

### Describe the bug

When using `gemini-cli` to connect to a GhidraMCP service, it fails with a `400 INVALID_ARGUMENT` error, specifically `Invalid function name`. However, the exact same GhidraMCP service works perfectly when accessed through the official Google Gemini extension in VS Code, which I understand is also powered by `gemini-cli`.

This suggests there is a difference in how `gemini-cli` processes or sanitizes function declarations from GhidraMCP when run standalone versus when it's integrated into the VS Code extension.

### Steps to Reproduce

1.  Set up a GhidraMCP server instance.
2.  Configure standalone `gemini-cli` to connect to this GhidraMCP service by adding it to the `tools` configuration.
3.  Attempt to use a feature that calls a GhidraMCP function via a prompt (e.g., `@ghidra decompile`).
4.  The command fails and returns the API error.
5.  Now, open VS Code with the Google Gemini extension.
6.  Configure the extension to point to the *same* GhidraMCP service endpoint.
7.  Use the chat feature in VS Code and make the same request (e.g., `@ghidra decompile`).
8.  The request succeeds, and the result from Ghidra is returned as expected.

### Expected Behavior

The standalone `gemini-cli` should be able to communicate with the GhidraMCP service without errors, just as it does when integrated within the VS Code extension. It should likely perform the same function name sanitization or validation before sending the request to the Gemini API.

### Actual Behavior

The standalone `gemini-cli` throws the following API error, preventing any interaction with the GhidraMCP service.

```json
âœ• [API Error: [{
    "error": {
      "code": 400,
      "message": "The GenerateContentRequest proto is invalid:\n  * 
  tools.function_declarations.name: [FIELD_INVALID] Invalid function name. Must start with 
  a letter or an underscore. Must be a-z, A-Z, 0-9, or contain underscores, dots and dashes, with 
  a maximum length of 64.",
      "errors": [
        {
          "message": "The GenerateContentRequest proto is invalid:\n  * 
  tools.function_declarations.name: [FIELD_INVALID] Invalid function name. Must start with 
  a letter or an underscore. Must be a-z, A-Z, 0-9, or contain underscores, dots and dashes, with 
  a maximum length of 64.",
          "domain": "global",
          "reason": "badRequest"
        }
      ],
      "status": "INVALID_ARGUMENT"
    }
  }
]]

### What did you expect to happen?

The standalone `gemini-cli` should be able to communicate with the GhidraMCP service without errors, just as it does when integrated within the VS Code extension. It should likely perform the same function name sanitization or validation before sending the request to the Gemini API.

When I execute a command targeting the GhidraMCP tool (e.g., `@ghidra decompile`), I expect the command to be processed successfully and the output from Ghidra to be displayed in my terminal, not an API error.

### Client information

About Gemini CLI                                         â”‚
â”‚                                                          â”‚
â”‚ CLI Version         0.1.13                               â”‚
â”‚ Model               gemini-2.5-pro                       â”‚
â”‚ Sandbox             no sandbox                           â”‚
â”‚ OS                  linux                                â”‚
â”‚ Auth Method         OAuth                                â”‚

### Login information

_No response_

### Anything else we need to know?

_No response_

nodes.body: @google-gemini note the actions failure for this issue: https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/actions/runs/16268351764/job/45929316364
I _think_ this is is similar to #4400-- consolidating by closing as duplicate but feel free to re-open if it's distinct
(see explanation in #4400 for why I re-opened this)

Thanks for reopening.

> But https://github.com/google-gemini/gemini-cli/issues/4127 should be re-opened, although I am not sure if MCP in general is intended to support integer enums, that is a different question.

In hour case weâ€˜re just exposing the rest api as mcp. As long as not forbidden by json schema Iâ€˜d expect them to be supported?

[JSON schema](https://json-schema.org/understanding-json-schema/reference/enum) does allow mixed types. The only restriction I see in MCP is for the primitive [EnumSchema](https://github.com/modelcontextprotocol/modelcontextprotocol/blob/main/schema/2025-06-18/schema.json#L679) which only applies to elicitations.

node.title: Checkpoint save race condition can result in function call/response mismatch after restore
node.body:
## Problem

When using `/chat save` to checkpoint a session, the Gemini CLI may serialize the chat history while asynchronous tool executions (function calls) are still pending. This can result in a checkpoint file (JSON) where the number of function call parts does not match the number of function response parts for one or more turns. When restoring such a checkpoint with `/chat resume`, the CLI attempts to use this history, which triggers API errors such as:

```
API Error: [{
    "error": {
      "code": 400,
      "message": "Please ensure that the number of function response parts is equal to the number of function call parts of the function call turn.",
      "errors": [
        {
          "message": "Please ensure that the number of function response parts is equal to the number of function call parts of the function call turn.",
          "domain": "global",
          "reason": "badRequest"
        }
      ],
      "status": "INVALID_ARGUMENT"
    }
  }
  ]
```

## Reproduction Steps

1. Start a chat session and trigger a tool (function call) that takes a noticeable time to complete.
2. While the UI appears idle (prompt available), immediately run `/chat save <tag>`.
3. Exit and restart Gemini CLI.
4. Run `/chat resume <tag>`.
5. Attempt any further interaction and observe API error or erratic model behavior.

## Expected Behavior
- Checkpointing should only serialize chat history when all asynchronous requests are complete, _or_ should insert pending stubs for any in-flight function calls to maintain function call/response count invariants.
- Restoring from a checkpoint should never result in a function call/response mismatch or API errors from the Gemini backend.

## Actual Behavior
- The CLI can save checkpoints with incomplete function call/response pairs, resulting in API errors or undefined behavior after `/chat resume`.

## Suggested Fix
- Before writing a checkpoint, block until all tool executions and function calls are complete.
- Alternatively, serialize incomplete turns with explicit pending stubs and handle them gracefully on restore (e.g., re-trigger the tool call or prompt the user).

## Additional Info
none

---
**Please prioritize this as it can corrupt user sessions and lead to unrecoverable API errors.**

node.title: Gemini-CLI Compression Error

### What happened?

The error occurs because my input exceeds the token limit for the Gemini 2.5 Flash model, even after compression. Here's a breakdown:

Key Issue:
Gemini 2.5 Flash's token limit: 1,048,576 tokens (as stated in the error).

Your compressed input: 1,624,359 tokens (per the error message).

Fix Compression Logic

nodes.body: Current MCP Servers are all coded according to the set standards, but Gemini uses a very strict chain transmission method, so it will report errors and cannot be used. I think the problem is that Gemini does not update to the latest method. Its creator is extremely conservative in his views. It's really trash.The only way to fix this is to pull the projects back and edit them yourself, edit the enums to the strings that gemini accepts, or replace the method completely

nodes.body: @maximilianosilva if you specifically install v0.1.10 it does work. But it seems to have broken for any versions both before and after that. I'm getting the same issue on the latest version (0.1.12 as of writing).

Current MCP Servers are all coded according to the set standards, but Gemini uses a very strict chain transmission method, so it will report errors and cannot be used. I think the problem is that Gemini does not update to the latest method. Its creator is extremely conservative in his views. It's really trash.The only way to fix this is to pull the projects back and edit them yourself, edit the enums to the strings that gemini accepts, or replace the method completely
